flashcards.back: "Don't even" is a slang expression meaning "not even" or "don't bother." It's used to warn someone not to do or say something, expressing surprise, outrage, or rejection.
flashcards.example:
Person 1: "Can you lend me some money?"
Person 2: "Don't even think about it."
We are fully committed to Equal Opportunity policies.

flashcards.front: someone or s.th is somthing else

flashcards.example: They're all good soccer players, but Mark is really something else.

1.Zero Conditional: Used to express a general truth or a scientific fact.
Example: "If you heat ice, it melts."

2.First Conditional: Used to express a future possibility or probability.
Example: "If it rains, I will stay at home."

3.Second Conditional: Used to express an imaginary or hypothetical situation.
Example: "If I won the lottery, I would buy a house."

4.Third Conditional: Used to express a hypothetical past situation and its hypothetical past result.
Example: "If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam."

1) Second Conditional: Describes a hypothetical ***present or future*** situation and its likely outcome.
If she had a car, she could drive to work.
If I knew how to swim, I would go to the beach more often.

2) Third Conditional: Describes a hypothetical ***past situation*** and its imagined result.
If I had gone to the party, I would have met her.
If I had studied harder, I would have passed the exam.

Mixed conditionals are a combination of two or more different conditionals (e.g. first, second, third) in one sentence to express a hypothetical situation and its outcome. These types of sentences are used to talk about a situation that started in the past and has consequences in the present or future.

Here are a few examples of mixed conditionals:

If she had listened to the advice, she wouldn't be in this situation now. (third conditional + second conditional)
If I had known about the traffic, I would be at work now. (third conditional + present simple)
If he had taken his umbrella, he wouldn't be wet now. (third conditional + present continuous)

flashcards.front: Umgangsprachliche "This is going to get you"
flashcards.example: "This is going to get you" bedeutet in der Regel, dass etwas negative Auswirkungen auf jemanden haben wird oder dass jemand in Schwierigkeiten geraten wird.

flashcards.back: es macht mich wahnsinnig wenn... دیوانه ام می کند
is used to express that we want a situation in the present (or future) to be different.
flashcards.example:
I wish I spoke Italian. (I don’t speak Italian)
I wish I had a big car. (I don’t have a big car)
I wish I were on a beach. (I’m in the office)
I wish it were the weekend. (It’s only Wednesday)

flashcards.back: wish + would + bare infinitive is used to express impatience, annoyance or dissatisfaction with a present action.
flashcards.example:
I wish you would stop smoking.
You are smoking at the moment and it is annoying me.

I wish it would stop raining.
I’m impatient because it is raining and I want to go outside.

I wish she’d be quiet.
I am annoyed because she is speaking.

flashcards.back: is used to express a regret, or that we want a situation in the past to be different.
flashcards.example:
I wish I hadn’t eaten so much. (I ate a lot)
I wish they’d come on holiday with us. (They didn’t come on holiday)
I wish I had studied harder at school. (I was lazy at school)

flashcards.back: used instead of "i wish" to express deep regret
flashcards.example: If only I had paid more attention in class, I would have understood the material better. (The speaker expresses regret about not paying enough attention in a past class, wishing they had understood the material better.)
